Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Using Osteohistology to Gain Further Insights Into the Growth, Physiology, and Behavior of the High Latitude Hypsilophodontids from Victoria, Australia

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
When most people think about what it would be like to study dinosaurs for a living, they probably imagine people lying on their stomachs scratching at dusty fossils with dental picks under a hot desert sun, or possibly someone examining huge bones from a skeleton in a museum. While these are definitely things that dinosaur paleontologists do, they can use a variety of additional techniques to learn more about these fascinating animals. I belong to a special branch of paleontology, called paleohistology. As a Ph.D. candidate at Montana State University, I am advised by Dr. Jack Horner and work at the Museum of the Rockies studying the bone microstructure of extinct animals, in most cases dinosaurs, to figure out how they were living and growing. My tools are not shovels and dental picks but rather grit plates and microscopes.

It seems very counter-intuitive: if you want to learn how dinosaurs were actually growing up, these huge animals must be examined microscopically. To actually see the bone tissue of a dinosaur, part of the bone must be removed and carried through a process that involves gluing the piece to a glass slide and progressively polishing it thinner and thinner until the miniscule structures preserved in the fossil are visible with a microscope. Then, looking at the arrangement of fibers in the bone tissue, as well as how the blood vessels were organized within the bone, the life history of that dinosaur is revealed- how fast it grew each year, how old it was when it died, how long it took to reach maturity.

I became interested in histology research on dinosaurs that were living near the South Pole, as surely if any dinosaur was going to be growing differently, the ones living in a cool, semi-annually dark environment would. Dr. Tom Rich, Senior Curator of Vertebrate Paleontology and Paleobotany at the Melbourne Museum in Victoria, Australia, had just the collection of dinosaur material I would need for such a study. Through the National Science Foundation’s East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program, I was given a unique opportunity to access this scientifically valuable collection, as the Australian specimens are too rare to risk shipping out of the country.

The data I collected from the polar dinosaur fossils yielded very interesting results. A previous microstructure study, based on much less material, suggested some dinosaurs living near the South Pole hibernated while others were active year-round. Because I had access to a larger sample, I was able to demonstrate that the bone microstructure of dinosaurs living near the South Pole was no different from dinosaurs living anywhere else in the world. As far as what bone microstructure could tell us, polar dinosaurs were living and growing the same as any other dinosaur and there was no evidence of hibernation. The broader implication of my results is that the ancestors of all dinosaurs possessed a physiology that enabled their descendents to exploit a variety of environmental conditions with no need for extreme physiological adaptations- at least none that would be evident in the bones. Results of this research are published in the online free access journal PLoS ONE.

In the two months I spent in Australia, I was able to establish international contacts and institute future collaborative opportunities between Melbourne Museum and the Museum of the Rockies. In fact, there is still more to be learned from the bone microstructure of polar dinosaurs, and with my Australian co-authors I intend to produce at least two more research papers from the data collected.
